title: Cohort Retention Heatmap
insights:
Insights from the Bus Ticket Booking App Dataset

The analysis of the dataset has provided valuable insights into user retention across different cohorts. Below are the findings based on the retention matrix and dataset summary.

1. BEST COHORT

The cohort from Week 52 (W52) has the strongest retention, with a Week 1 retention rate of 71.4% (n=7). This high retention could be attributed to several factors:

  • Seasonality: Week 52 coincides with the holiday season, which typically sees increased travel activity.
  • Marketing Campaigns: There may have been targeted promotions during this period to encourage bookings.
  • User Experience Improvements: If any product changes were implemented prior to this cohort, they may have positively influenced user satisfaction.

2. WORST COHORT

The cohort from Week 2 (W2) shows the fastest drop-off, with a Week 1 retention rate of 4.1% and a Week 2 retention rate of 0.0%. This significant decline indicates that users are not finding enough value to return after their initial experience.

3. OVERALL TREND

Retention appears to be declining across successive cohorts. The Week 1 retention rates for W1 (7.6%) and W2 (4.1%) show a downward trend, suggesting that recent changes or user engagement strategies may not be effective in retaining users over time.

4. RETENTION STRATEGIES

To improve Week 1 retention, the following strategies are recommended:

  • Enhance Onboarding Experience: Given the low retention in W1 (7.6%), improving the onboarding process could help users understand the app's value proposition better and encourage them to return.
  • Targeted Re-engagement Campaigns: Implementing campaigns specifically aimed at users who drop off after their first use could help bring them back. The stark drop in W2 retention (0.0%) indicates a need for strategies to re-engage users who may have had a poor initial experience.
